talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm, without traversing any operational matters, whether investigations by the Australian Federal Police into leaked finance department documents regarding the millennium bug have yet been completed? The minister may be aware that these documents expose the Howard cabinet short-changing 37 departments and agencies by more than 50 per cent or $110 million in their attempts to solve internal Y2K problems. Have the Federal Police spoken to agencies such as Tax, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Foreign Affairs about the matter?

—I thank Senator Lundy for the question. I would not have thought it would come as a surprise to Senator Lundy to be told that on a day-to-day basis I am not kept informed on operational matters—nor should I be, nor should any minister be. There will be occasions when operational matters in relation to certain operations will be relevant for a minister to know. This is not one such matter. I will ask the AFP to provide me with such material as they believe is appropriate. If there is any material, you will get it quickly.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What does it say about the government's priorities, Minister, when resources are so quickly put towards police investigations into leaked documents, when those documents state that CASA received only 37 per cent of the $7 million it needs to fix Y2K problems in their computer systems?

—Senator Lundy, I do not immediately attribute to you the characteristic of quoting things that are not correct. I simply say that I do not accept at face value what you say. I have not had the opportunity to check what you put forward, but I will take that opportunity. The government has a wide-ranging law enforcement priority. It is always a difficulty deciding where to spend the limited amounts of money that are available. You will be aware of the very good work we are doing with our Tough on Drugs strategy, but make no bones about it, Senator Lundy: public servants who leak documents are breaking the law. If you want to come into this place and suggest that it should be a free-for-all for public servants to release whatever information they like, that they can somehow have access to material of government that the rest of the public do not have, and that when they feel like it they can release it with complete freedom, then you do so. But you will not have anyone on this side of the chamber or anyone interested in proper government agreeing with you.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. It relates to the government's tax reform plan and the enormous benefits for Australian industry and jobs. Will the minister outline how the costs of doing business will be reduced, real jobs will be created and economic growth strengthened as a result of the government's plan? Also, will the minister explain how the practical needs of Australian industry will be reflected in the process?

—The new tax system which we propose to introduce is a vital part of ensuring that Australian business can compete, can create wealth, can create jobs. It is true that the Labor government in 13 years did a few good things. They did actually start the process of opening the Australian economy up—with our support, and I am sure they appreciate the support they received. But they only half did the job. The problem was that they exposed Australian industry to international competition but they left Australian industry with its legs tied together: they did nothing to ensure that Australian businesses could compete in the new world which Labor exposed them to. The two critical areas where they did nothing to ensure Australian industry could compete were labour market reform and tax reform. Those two issues have to be addressed if you are going to expose Australian industry to international competition. Without any help from Labor we have moved on those two fronts—most importantly now on tax reform.

answer.para: The current wholesale sales tax system which this Labor opposition is standing here to defend to the last drop is without doubt the most hopeless indirect tax system in the world. It is a huge burden on manufacturing, which you say you support and defend. The worst effect is on the car industry—again, an industry you say you support and will defend. It may not be known to many—probably not to the opposition—that the car industry is actually responsible for paying one quarter of all of the wholesale sales tax revenue. One industry, the car industry, pays one quarter of all the wholesale sales tax collected in this country.

There are a lot of reasons why the Labor Party in South Australia is very unpopular: one of them is the Bolkus Left and its machinations; another is the excellent representation from the Liberal Party. But the burden that this Labor opposition wants to keep on the car industry—your tax, Labor's 22 per cent tax that they want to keep on the industry—is critical to Labor's unpopularity and the reason that Labor's worst state is South Australia. Of course, Labor's idea of reforming the wholesale sales tax system is to add caviar and Lear jets and take the tax off orange juice. That is brilliant. What a great approach to reforming the wholesale sales tax system. Among the anomalies, I referred to the frozen yoghurt problem with wholesale sales tax. There are a number of others. Paper cups used on commercial premises are taxed at 12 per cent but those used in takeaway stores are taxed at 22 per cent. Chairs used at home are taxed at 12 per cent; chairs used by businesses are taxed at 22 per cent. Filing cabinets are taxed at 22 per cent, but one- or two-drawer timber filing cabinets using materials of less than 17 millimetres are taxed at 12 per cent. You expect Australian industry to keep complying with this sort of nonsense, and you are going to try to vote down a new tax system that will benefit Australian industry in order to defend this absolute nonsense.

I remind the Senate that under our new tax system Australian industry is going to save $10,000 million a year in costs. Savings to the car manufacturing industry will be $1,150 million every year; savings for the mining industry will be $2,970 million a year; savings for the construction industry will be $3,740 million a year; savings for our exporters will be $4,500 million a year; and changes to the fuel regime will save businesses $3,500 million a year. You lot—the ALP opposition—will stand there to oppose all of these savings, which will be all about creating jobs. You are a policy free zone. You do not believe in creating jobs. You do not believe in helping Australian industry.

—My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. The Howard coalition government was re-elected on a mandate to implement a 30 per cent rebate for people who took out private health insurance. This is equivalent to the saving, on average, of $750 per person. Can the minister outline the benefits this initiative will have for the nation's health system, and is there widespread community support for that?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lightfoot for the question. It is a very substantial question that has much more relevance than the question that was asked by the opposition prior to Senator Lightfoot asking his question.

answer.para: The $750 relates to the family that the rebate will bring in. As Senator Lightfoot said, a central plank to the government's tax package was the introduction of the 30 per cent tax rebate for people who take out private health insurance. This initiative will have the added benefit of creating a stronger Australian health care system by alleviating some of the pressure on the public health system. This government is committed to maintaining a strong balance between public and private health sectors so that Australians have a choice when it comes to health care. Our promise includes a stronger public system, retaining Medicare with a record $31.3 billion of funding for public hospitals in the next five years. Part of this commitment includes ensuring the public health sector is complemented by a private sector that is fair, affordable, customer friendly and good value for money.

We introduced legislation for the 30 per cent rebate in the last sittings. It will restore balance to the health system by slowing the drop-out rate that Labor left to run wild like a bushfire. This is about continuing to help low income earners who scrimp and save to give themselves the security of private health insurance.

talk.start.para: —What?

—Madam President, Senator Cook says `Rubbish!' In the time that the Labor Party was in power, Senator Cook may be interested to know, the proportion of the population covered by private health insurance dropped from 70 per cent to 35 per cent. Senator Cook may also be interested to know that the premiums trebled under Labor. So it was a double whammy under Labor. For Senator Cook to call out `rubbish', it is obvious to me that he has not got a clue what he is talking about—which is consistent with his general approach overall.

answer.para: This is about continuing to help low income earners who scrimp and save to give themselves the security of private health insurance. I am advised that at least 700,000 Australians earning less than $20,000 a year have private health insurance. A family or an older couple paying $2,500 a year in private health premiums will get back about $750 from the government every year. This is effectively a tax cut, and the Labor Party wants to block it.

In Queensland, my home state, there are almost one million people covered by private health insurance. In the Queensland electorate of Groom, for example, 20,000 people will benefit if the Senate passes this legislation. It will put $10 million a year directly into the pockets of the people of Groom. This rebate has substantial support in the community. The latest research by Quantum Harris shows 67 per cent of those polled believe the government should do more to encourage people to take out or retain private health insurance. Seventy-three per cent would prefer to choose their own doctor if they go to hospital; an option only available as a private patient. The research also found that 59 per cent believe the best way to support people with private health insurance is to make premiums tax deductible.

We are giving people what they want. It is about fairness and freedom of choice. Labor does not know about these concepts, and you can understand Senator Cook's interjection in that context. They are ideologically opposed to private health care. They cannot open their minds to what Australians want, and it is a demonstration of why they did not win the last election. It is because they are locked in the politics, rhetoric and ideology of the past. Their own former health minister Graham Richardson knew this when he was minister, and he is still saying it today. This is what he said this week about the Labor Party:

They simply don't want to acknowledge that private health care matters. There is an ideological bent here that says Medicare is perfect, which is ridiculous, and therefore can't be changed, which is also ridiculous, and therefore nothing should be done to private health, which is also ridiculous.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice. Minister, can you confirm that the Australian Federal Police is currently losing agents at the rate of some 13 per month and that it has lost some 185 agents in the past 12 months? Can you also confirm that not all of the promised resources for mobile strike teams have yet come on stream and that, as a consequence, the AFP has been forced to pay for operations by selling major assets? Minister, will you make representations, as you should, to your cabinet colleagues in order to quickly redress the funding crisis afflicting the Australian Federal Police?

—Senator Bolkus is, sadly, a slow learner, but we will go through this again. Sooner or later he will cotton on, or perhaps finally Mr Beazley will cotton on and give him the flick. The situation is this: the AFP did start losing personnel under the Labor government, and that continued for a period under this government. Labor increased the savings that were to be had from the AFP. This government has put more money in the first three years of its term into the AFP than in the last three years under Labor. That is perhaps the simplest explanation. We have specially targeted some of that money, and it is well known that a large amount of that money is targeted to the Tough on Drugs strategy.

answer.para: I attended, earlier this year, what I think was the largest intake of recruits as federal agents in the past 10 years. So, Senator Bolkus, the bottom line is this: you left the AFP in a shocking mess. Our Prime Minister committed to making it a police force second to none in the world. We are putting the money and resources into doing that. We promised an additional four mobile strike teams during the election, and not all of that money has come on stream yet. I just make the point that, under Labor, there was the capacity for only one major drug investigation by the AFP—not one investigation; one major one. We have now committed funds for 10 mobile strike teams to target drugs around Australia, and we have seen in the last couple of months the rewards that that brings. Sena tor Bolkus, you could do better for the third question.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it a fact that over these four years you have provided funding to the AFP at some $159 million dollars less than the 1996-97 level? Isn't it also a fact that people are leaving the AFP in record numbers? Given the persistent nature of the criticism of the funding of the AFP, will you immediately authorise the public release of the Ayers report so that public confidence can be restored in the AFP? If not, why not?
—The only persistent questioning on funding for the AFP comes from Senator Bolkus. He appears to have nothing else to do. No, I am not going to do something because Senator Bolkus is bored.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Of course I am not. We appointed an appropriate, independent inquiry into the AFP because the Prime Minister wanted to ensure that it was properly funded to face the challenges of the year 2000. We have committed to implementing the Ayers report, and we will do that. They may miss being in government. They may want to have all the documents government has; the sad fact is that they got a chance at it at the last election, and they lost. I am sorry—the answer is no.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Is it the case, Minister, that in 1994 the Prices Surveillance Authority concluded that bank fees should not, in aggregate, be increased? Does the minister know that in 1996 the Treasurer told parliament that red-hot competition was needed to regulate fees and that the government would take action, if necessary, if competition was inadequate. Do you acknowledge that the Treasurer found, in September 1997, the government was not assured that fees were adequately competitive to ensure fair pricing? A year later, the situation is worse. Minister, what is your government going to do to keep banking affordable for ordinary Australians?

—Let me make a number of comments on that question. The first thing, of course, is that people borrowing from banks are receiving mortgage rates at a level that the Labor Party could only dream of. One of the many achievements of this government has been to deliver very low interest rates to Australians. Another achievement of this government is that we are removing a range of taxes on financial activities—the FIDs and the BADs—and that is also a very big plus. You asked what we are doing about those things. Well, Senator, look at the taxes we are removing as part of our tax reform package. I think that will be widely welcomed by the community.

answer.para: The government does not determine the policies or guidelines that the banks adopt in levying fees and charges—any more than we determine the price of food in a supermarket. These are a response to increased competition which was necessitated by the removal of past subsidies. Bank customers can maximise the benefits of competition by actively shopping around for the best products, services and prices to satisfy their needs. Many deposit taking institutions continue to offer basic transaction accounts with lower fees and charges. For example, all the four major banks offer basic transaction accounts without monthly account keeping fees, although they do have over-the-counter fees. Building societies and credit unions offer competitive everyday accounts.

Senator, there is an issue here, and let me assure you the government is not ignoring this matter. A new framework for the Commonwealth regulation of the financial sector commenced on 1 July 1998. The government considers that this package of measures will enhance competition and lead to better services and lower prices than would otherwise have been the case. We are also investigating what can be done to address the difficulties that fees and charges impose on those receiving government transfer payments, which are generally provided by direct credit to a nominated account with a bank, building society or credit union.

Increased competition has reduced interest rate margins, particularly for housing loans. This has required banks to price services more directly to the cost of their provision and, as I said, previous cross-subsidies have either been reduced or removed. We believe that the overall cost of banking, particularly when you take into account the very substantial falls in interest rates which have occurred, are providing better service to the public—
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Conroy—cease interjecting.
—I think that is very important. As I have said, because of the increased competitive arrangements, banks have got to price their products more directly.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Assistant Treasurer: is your position different from that of the Treasurer? The minister failed to acknowledge whether or not the Treasurer believes that action is necessary if competition is inadequate. If competition is inadequate when it comes to price fixing and fees, are you prepared to take action, like the Treasurer said you should? Is your position different from the Treasurer's? Are you aware that, following the announcement by the Commonwealth Bank that fees would increase, the price of shares rose 66c? Does the government think that what is good for shareholders is also good for customers? If the answer is yes, what do you say to those whose spending money—which is all they have—will be significantly eaten into by increased fees? Minister, is your position the same as that of the Treasurer?
—Let me assure you that I am in blazing agreement with the Treasurer. In fact, so many of the actions that we have taken in relation to financial markets have been to increase competition.

answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Precisely. That is what we have done. I have mentioned to you that one of the reasons that interest rates—

answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator, you have had a chance to ask your question; I am now seeking to reply to it. Madam President, it is very difficult to respond to a question when the questioner keeps on talking. The government will maintain its policy of informal monitoring of bank fees and charges and opposing unfair and anti-competitive practices. The major banks voluntarily inform the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission of their movements in fees and charges.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm claims made by the Institute of Chartered Accountants that Australia is losing up to $3.5 billion per year to fraud and is in danger of a fraud epidemic? Can the minister also confirm that the growth areas for fraud have been identified as credit cards, business fraud and money laundering, especially over the Internet? Further, can the minister confirm that the investigation of fraud is one of the principal areas that has been affected by the government's budget cuts? Will the government be taking this report seriously? What steps does the government propose to take to remedy the problem?

—I thank the senator for her question. No, Senator, the report of the Institute of Chartered Accountants does not immediately come to mind. An assessment of $3.5 billion of the cost of fraud would seem to me to be very light on; but that is an anecdotal assessment. I will have a look at what the report has to say about its assessment of $3.5 billion.

answer.para: Fraud is an enormous cost to the Australian community and to federal, state and local governments. It is a very serious matter. It is part of the AFP's charter to look at fraud, as it is the charter of each of the state and territory police forces. It is not solely a Commonwealth matter, although it is a very important matter for the Commonwealth. Of course it would be true that as technology develops so do opportunities for crooks to undertake fraudulent activities. Credit cards, banking fraud and money laundering, especially using the net, are of course problems. If you want a copy of a book which has been recently released by the Institute of Criminology, Crime in the Digital Age, if you are interested in the new directions for law enforcement, then I can certainly provide you with a copy of that book and some other material in relation to this matter.

I assure you it is a matter of concern to the government. No, I do not accept that cuts to the AFP have occasioned a reduction in their effort in this respect. As I have indicated, in our first three years in government we have put more money into the Federal Police than your government put in in your last three years in government. So I find it difficult to say, `Yes, we've had these dramatic cuts.' As you know, we have put significant amounts of money in and we have targeted drugs, but that is the additional moneys. The AFP's commitment to combating fraud remains.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister reassure the Senate that the Commonwealth government will continue to have strict guidelines for the use of credit cards by its employees, unlike the Rafferty's rules which apply to the Victorian government where credit cards have become a licence to steal?

—Senator Denman invites me to make a comparison with another government. It is not my place to make that comparison. I do not know about other ministers but I know that I do not use a credit card. I think ministers in the previous government used them. My understanding is that this government has a practice where, if ministers need to purchase something as a consequence of their duties, they put in a claim, certify what it is for and are paid back. You invite me, Senator Denman, to make some inquiries about the practice of credit card charging under the previous government so that I can give you a good comparison.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Theft of Drugs and Money

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. It relates to allegations that drugs and money were found to be missing as a consequence of audits of exhibits and drugs in the Australian Federal Police and that large quantities of counterfeit banknotes were not destroyed as quickly as they should have been in the circumstances. Will the minister inform the Senate about the accuracy of such claims?

—I thank Senator Coonan for her question. The stories in relation to drugs and money and other matters from the AFP show that, if you are prepared to selectively quote, if you are prepared to ignore available facts, you can get yourself a very good by-line as a journalist and be in the spotlight if you are in opposition and suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome—identified by Gareth Evans. Sadly, when the facts are not checked or when they are ignored and stories are run and picked up by other media, the reputation of people and organisations can be unfairly and unjustly smeared.

answer.para: The stories centre on some internal audits done by the AFP, on their own instigation, to keep their practices up to date. The catalyst for these series of audits was an incident in the late 1980s and early 1990s—when Labor was in power—when a relatively small amount of money went missing. So the AFP said, `We'd better keep a constant watch on these practices.' As a consequence of these stories running, some people have been led to believe—and you would, if you read the articles—that these audits discovered that drugs, money and other exhibits had been stolen from the AFP by the AFP. This is simply untrue. It is a gross slur on the Australian Federal Police.

The stories put into question the ethics of the Australian Federal Police, but I think they question the ethics of the writer, and of Mr Kerr who has been so willing to fuel the flames in this matter. It is hard enough for our law enforcement agencies to fight the crooks, let alone to put up with fighting this kind of rubbish in the media. The facts are these. The auditors did not discover any loss of money or drugs and they found no evidence of corruption. The relevant journalist was invited to attend my office with the auditors to indicate the basis on which his conclusions were drawn, because this is a very serious matter. He declined to do so but provided some quotes from the reports on which he had relied. It is fair to say that he has selectively quoted in order either to create a misunderstanding or an impression which is simply untrue. As an example, he constantly referred in articles to money having been stolen. That is the money that was seized in the 1980s and found not to be there in the 1990s—under Labor—which started the audit process off. In other words, the catalyst for the good practice of regularly auditing your work practices has in fact become the conclusion.

The journalist today raises problems allegedly faced by the AFP in getting approval to destroy counterfeit notes, and if you read these articles you would think Peter Costello was to blame for a security risk in the Federal Police. One of the articles starts:
Treasurer Peter Costello increased the chances of counterfeit currency disappearing, audit reports reveal.
Somewhere else it refers to `the inability of the AFP to obtain authorisation'. And on it goes, associating the matter with the Treasurer.

talk.start.para: —That's a direct quote from the Audit report.

—That is a direct quote out of context. The reports assert that counterfeit notes—and plenty of them; we are talking about tens of millions of dollars of counterfeit notes—were not destroyed because the AFP was unable to get approval from Mr Costello. The truth of the matter is that the first request was made to Treasurer Keating in 1992 and it was ignored. The second request was made to Treasurer Willis in 1995 and no approval was given. Within six weeks of this government being asked for approval to destroy the notes, the approval was given. That is the end of the story. If you want to question the journalist's reason for writing the article, you need look no further than today's articles that seek to blame Treasurer Costello. The truth is it was Labor's delay. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Has the minister or anyone else in the government referred any matters in the Auditor-General's report No. 10 on the sale of one-third of Telstra to the Federal Police or to any other investigative agency? If not, why not?

If there is anything I have to say about it, I will come back to you. For the fifth or sixth question of the day—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You found a report and you think there is a slight glimmer of hope that you will find something negative in there and you ask whether I will therefore take it up and follow it through for you. The answer is yes, if you think there is something in there I will ask the minister for finance about it and come back to you with a proper answer.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to recent reports of increased violence and murders in East Timor. Is the minister aware that the United States government is concerned that 44 people were killed during a recent military sweep in East Timor? Is he also aware that Portugal suspended the United Nations brokered talks with Indonesia last Friday after the reported killings near the town of Alas, and that Portugal has called for an international investigation into the allegations of military involvement in these killings? Will the Australian government join with the Portuguese government in calling for an international investigation?

—Yes, we are aware and are obviously disturbed by reports of new violence and killings of villagers, in particular in the area of Alas in south-central East Timor. Our embassy in Jakarta is endeavouring to establish the veracity of the reports. To date the embassy has obtained information from several sources, although reports are conflicting. The ICRC has indicated that although the situation in the village of Alas has become very tense and some houses have been burnt, there is no evidence of troops having opened fire on the local population. This information however is by no means conclusive and does not rule out the possibility that non-combatants might have been killed in the course of military operations. The embassy will continue its efforts to establish precisely what did occur.

answer.para: Yes, we are aware that these allegations have led to delay of the official level tripartite talks in New York until clarification is obtained. This, of course, underlines the need for all sides of the conflict to exercise restraint and refrain from the use of violence so that negotiations for a just and lasting settlement might proceed. In summary, we are anxious for progress to be made on a long-term, peaceful and just settlement of the East Timor problems and therefore, apart from the fact that we regret any violence, particularly violence that is destabilising or decreases the chances of achieving that goal, the Australian government will continue to do what it can to support positively the continuation of that process to a fair and just conclusion.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for his answer and I note that. I also note that the foreign minister said in today's Australian that business confidence cannot be separated from the achievement of a successful transition to a more open and democratic political system in Indonesia—and I have to agree with him. I think we need to maintain pressure on the Indonesian government to behave responsibly towards all its citizens, to decrease troop levels within East Timor—although there have been signs that that has occurred; on the other hand, troop numbers are still at a very high level—and to find other ways to decrease tension and hopefully move positively towards this fair and just solution.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney-General. I refer the minister to reports of comments of the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that the government's proposed changes to the tribunal would create a bureaucratic nightmare that could be barely be imagined. Is the minister aware of the comments of Justice Mathews, who stated that there were so many problems with the proposals that, if they were implemented, there would be very limited benefit to the community and very great cost in terms of both the quality and the independence of the external merit review of decisions by the public service. I do not believe that to say it was done behind closed doors by people who clearly know little about this is at all a fair assessment by Justice Mathews.

answer.para: Coming to the earlier part of your question: it is not uncommon for people associated with institutions which are the subject of reform to resist that reform in one way or another. In fact, it is very common for people or the institutions they are associated with to complain when the reform process is under way. The Attorney has announced a reform process. We have confidence in it and I am sure it will deliver better outcomes to the Australian people. I accept, however, that there are people with different views. Justice Mathews is clearly one of them. One might think more of her view if she was not so closely involved as part of the reform process; in other words, if her institution was not one of the ones to be reformed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, Justice Mathews was not the only one to criticise. Although her criticism was stinging of the government's proposal there was also opposition to proposed changes from the Law Council and from leading administrative lawyers. Will you, Minister, act to review the planned changes or is this just another example of a government blinded by arrogance, unwilling to heed the advice of senior figures in the justice system?

—This is a matter for the Attorney, so it would not be me that redid it, in any event. The critical point, Senator McKiernan, is that you say there are other people who disagree. I have no doubt there are other people who disagree. Something your government always had an incapacity to accept is that some people will disagree. Your government was so ego driven that it required 99 per cent approval. That is why you always engaged in the pursuit of people who disagreed with you, to try to wipe them out of future career opportunities. That is what your government did. This government is much more accepting of people who have a different view. On this occasion, there may be people who have different views. Guess what? That is a part of the democratic system. —I recognise, again, Senator Harradine's interest in this very important matter and that it has been a struggle to progress. Nevertheless, real progress does seem to be being made at present and I think Senator Harradine in his question was recognising the amendments we made at the Commonwealth level to facilitate a bilateral agreement between China and the appropriate state which will set the standard for Austral ian adoptions from China. answer.para: Recent changes to China's adoption law, as reported in some Australian newspapers—I noticed it in the Age—will not affect the need for a formal agreement between China and Australia before Australians can adopt children from China. When the agreement is in place, the adoption, which will always take place in China, will be recognised in Australia. On entry to Australia these children will not come under the I(GOC) Act and there will be no need for the parents to seek further recognition of the adoption through an Australian court. Migration regulations have been amended to facilitate adoptions under the proposed bilateral agreement with China, as I said. They will come into force from the date the agreement comes into force. It has been a long time coming but it looks now as if the matter should be concluded within the next six months.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Senator Chapman is quite right—many people have said to me that we are the only country in the Western world to have gone down that path, but I always ask, `Who else has?' I suspect that there really is not any other country in the entire world that has had the courage to take on a new taxation system as the centrepiece of its election campaign. answer.para: I am asked whether there are any alternative approaches. The Labor Party's approach was basically to throw in a capital gains tax to try to ruin the nest egg of many small business people who were expecting that it would serve as their retirement package and to drop in that wonderful Toorak tractor initiative, which of course they thought applied only in a few metropolitan areas and which they rapidly discovered, to their dismay, affected vast numbers of people in the rural areas. talk.start.para: —I have not heard of him.

—I have hardly heard of him either, but I met him recently so he does exist. Joel Fitzgibbon was on the Small Business Show a matter of only 10 days ago and he said that someone, a small business operator, had spoken to him and said that she could afford to put on one more person, and would like to put on one more person, but she was fearful of unfair dismissals and she was fearful of going through the barrier to another level of red tape and regulation. If it is coming as close to home as that, you ought to take it seriously, but of course they do not. They simply are not prepared to take any notice of what is happening in the real world, because the Labor Party is actually dominated by the trade union movement. So if the union says, `We don't like unfair dismissals,' the ALP says, `Well, certainly not; we don't either.'

answer.para: If you go back a decade, and if you look over there, you find that of the nine longest serving ALP senators, only two were trade unionists. At that time 41 per cent of the work force were in trade unions. If you come forward a decade, the proportion of the work force in trade unions is down to 30 per cent. But what do we on this side find out about membership of the Labor Party? We find that eight out of the last 10 have been trade union officials, and 17 out of the last 20—65 per cent. In other words, while there has been a rapid decline in the community in terms of trade union membership, this has become the ultimate retirement village. Two-thirds of them have trade union ties; two-thirds of them have to take their instructions from trade union conferences. Madam President, it is an absolute disgrace. Plenty of good PhDs could be written about the sociological demise of the ALP, but you do not have to look much further than that to understand why it is they are not interested in policies any more. The answers read as follows—
RESPONSE TO QUESTION FROM SENATOR CHRIS EVANS ON GST & PUBLIC HOUSING RENTS
Senator Evans asked me a total of five questions yesterday on GST and public housing. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard additional responses to those questions.

para.inline: Will public housing rents be input taxed in the same manner that private residential rents will be taxed?

speech.para: Yes.

para.inline: Will State Governments receive a GST exemption from building inputs that are used to provide public housing?

speech.para: No.

para.inline: If not, how will state governments recover the extra capital costs of public housing due to the GST?

speech.para: State public housing authorities will no longer have to pay imbedded wholesale sales taxes on a' range of current inputs. Also, public housing tenants will have significantly greater disposable income as a result of the Government's tax reform policies. It could also be noted that state governments' finances as a whole will benefit substantially from taxation reform.

para.inline: Will they be required to increase public housing rents and increase public housing subsidies, or will they have to cut services?

speech.para: There will be no requirement on state governments to do any of these things.

para.inline: Given that many states automatically increase public housing rents in conjunction with CPI increases in social security payments, how will the Federal Government ensure that public housing rents will not increase as a result of the Government's inflationary GST?

speech.para: The Government's tax reform proposals are designed to ensure that all Australians, including social security recipients, enjoy the benefits that only comprehensive taxation reform can offer. In particular, the Government's package provides a range of benefits to social security recipients to more than compensate them for the price impact of the GST.

talk.start.para: —On 12 November last, Senator Jacinta Collins asked me a question about the Commonwealth government's response to the Victorian gas crisis. I seek leave to incorporate some supplementary information into the Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

para.inline: Response to Senator Jacinta Collins,.12 November 1998

speech.para: As announced by the Prime Minister on 2 October 1998, the Commonwealth Government is providing financial assistance, of up to $100 million, to assist eligible individuals as well as small businesses and community organisations in Victoria and New South Wales that incurred additional costs as a result of the Victorian gas emergency.
Following agreements with the Victorian and New South Wales Premiers, these States are administering the major components of the financial assistance package.

An advance of $50 million has been transferred by the Commonwealth to a trust account, which has been established for the purpose, and is administered by the Victorian Department of Treasury and Finance.

Advertisements have been placed in newspapers, including foreign language newspapers, outlining eligibility for this assistance and providing `hotlines' for assistance and application forms for the Small Business Component of the package.
The assistance package consists of three components:

Cash grants equivalent to Newstart allowance to workers who were stood down or had to close their small businesses and were unable to access Newstart assistance through Centrelink because they did not satisfy the normal conditions such as the waiting periods.
Assistance for small businesses, including primary producers, for additional costs which were incurred as a direct result of the interruption of gas supplies for operational purposes.

Emergency relief funding for community organisations dealing with the frail, the aged, the disabled and other disadvantaged groups in the community—for example in respect of food vouchers and assistance for repair or replacement of pensioners' gas appliances which failed when reconnected.

This assistance is not in the form of compensation for losses which may have been incurred it is financial assistance to defined small businesses, needy individuals and community organisations which meet the eligibility criteria.
Those people that may have made `private arrangements' in relation to the Victorian gas
crisis are able to claim under any or all of the three components to the rescue package
provided that they come under the eligibility criteria established for each component.

talk.start.para: —I have a response to a question asked by Senator Brown yesterday. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Reported killings at Biak, Irian Java
Senator Brown asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on 23 November 1998

1. What information does the Government have about the massacre at Biak and the subsequent murder of up to 137 people aboard an Indonesian ship where they were taken offshore from Biak following the raising of the West Papuan flag on the morning of 1 July in Biak?

2. What form of protest has the Government made to the Indonesian authorities and what moves is the Government making to ensure a full, open and independent international inquiry into this shocking set of events?
3. When did the Government approach two Australians, Mr Paul Meixner and Ms Rebecca Casey, who were in a house adjacent to the wharf when the original massacre took place?

4. Will the Minister be able to report back to me or to the Senate about the safety of up to 20 political prisoners, including Dr Philip Karma, who were dragged from their homes and have been charged with rebellion following the massacres by the Indonesian troops?
Senator Hill—The answer to the Senator's question is as follows:

1. An officer from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta visited Biak 11-14 July this year and looked into initial reports of the incident. Based on this visit the Australian Embassy has few doubts that human rights abuses did occur and that the security authorities used excessive force against members of the local community. The Australian Embassy has received differing reports from NGO and Church sources (indeed, between Church sources), from the Indonesian Military, from an Indonesian Parliamentary fact-finding team, and from the Indonesian Human Rights Commission (Komnas Ham). The Embassy also spoke to Australian Volunteers Abroad members, Mr Paul Meixner and Ms Rebecca Casey during a visit to Biak on 11-14 July. The range of estimated deaths from these various sources went from one to over 100. The source who provided Mr Meixner and Ms Casey with information, reported that he knew of 20 people who had died, and made mention of some people who had been dropped off a boat at sea. Allegations of bodies being dumped at sea—while if true are obviously of grave concern—have been the most difficult to confirm. Indonesian National Human Rights Commission told the Embassy that they could not establish a positive link between bodies that had washed up on the shore and the Biak incident.

2. Mr Downer raised his concerns personally about the Biak incident, and human rights in Irian Jaya in general, with President Habibie and Indonesian Ministers Wiranto and Alatas during his visit to Jakarta, 8-10 July this year. He called for the authorities to exercise restraint in its relations the community. Mr Downer also discussed the issue with Komnas Ham, which subsequently sent a fact-finding mission to Irian Jaya. On 14 November Mr Downer again raised the Biak incident with Mr Alatas when they met at the APEC meeting in Kuala Lumpur. The Embassy has followed up on the Minister's July representations, including during visits to Irian Jaya between 31 July and 5 August.

The Australian Embassy raised the issue with the military authorities and the vice-Governor of Irian Jaya, and has consistently urged the Indonesian military to exercise restraint in dealing with civil protests, where-ever these occur in Indonesia.
3. An officer of the Australian Embassy spoke to Mr Paul Meixner and Ms Rebecca Casey during a visit to Biak on 11-14 July.
4. The Embassy is following up with the ICRC on the question of the Dr Karma and others arrested at the time of the Biak incident.

talk.start.para: —I move:

You get the usual answer from Senator Alston. Do you know what Senator Alston is trying to do? He is trying to undermine Senator Hill at every opportunity. talk.start.para: —But he's a lawyer too.

speech.para: They have seven lawyers out of nine ministers on their frontbench, and Senator Alston has the hide to attack—hypocritically—the Labor Party for not being representative of the community. talk.start.para: —Something that we have come to experience in this Senate is that when Senator Faulkner does not have an argument he gets louder and louder to try to obviate the fact that he does not have any substance to his argument. I would have thought that the people of Australia listening in to this debate would have been wondering whether the people on the other side had just engaged in frolics of their own or were genuinely concerned about the issues confronting this nation.

speech.para: Where were their policy questions today about tax reform, health reform and balancing the budget? What about industrial relations reform? What about getting the unemployment rate down? They are not interested in the issues of the day. They want to go on frolics of their own, to talk about the background of ministers. Senator Carr interjecting—

There are no policies, Senator Faulkner, so all you can do is launch this absolutely pathetic attack. It has been one of your more dismal performances today, but the good thing is that the people of Australia do not need to rely on you and your side to govern this country.

talk.start.para: —Senator Abetz appears to refer to a policy free zone. talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Ray, be careful not to reflect upon honourable members opposite, please.

speech.para: There are two out of nine ministers who are not lawyers, yet they claim they are representative. Do we want to do an add-up of the rest of the lawyers on that side? There is nothing wrong with lawyers, but do not come into this chamber with double standards and hypocrisy and talk about representation, because it just won't wash.

Deep behind these comments by Senator Alston is reflected a degree of arrogance and elitism in that people are denigrated for the job they did prior to getting into this chamber. When you rubbish people in this chamber, you have always got to remember that, no matter what side they sit on, they beat someone to get here, usually hot competition. talk.start.para: —I am quite sure that anybody listening to the broadcast of the Senate today would wonder what exactly are the most important things that are confronting this nation today. We had a supposed concerted attack on Senator Vanstone today. Nearly every question was directed to Senator Vanstone on a variety of issues, which Senator Vanstone answered quite well. The tactic was to be to take note of Senator Vanstone's answers, but all of a sudden there was a last-minute change in tactics because Senator Vanstone answered the questions so completely that in fact they had nothing to take note of. speech.para: I am quite sure that those listening to this broadcast and those in the gallery today would be quite dismayed to think that the most important thing that the Labor Party could raise in taking note of answers to questions today is the composition of the Senate because Senator Alston happened to make some remarks about the composition of the opposition. Senator Ray says that Senator Alston smeared the opposition. If being referred to as a trade unionist is a smear, I would have thought that some of the people on the other side ought to change their attitude, because I would have thought that senators opposite would have been proud to be trade union members. In fact, many of them probably should have stayed in the jobs they were in before they came here because they come in here representing only the unions' point of view without looking at what is for the benefit of the bulk of the Australian people when we are considering legislation.

One of the differences is that when Senator Faulkner refers to the number of people on this side of the chamber with law degrees it is because many of those people have chosen to seek tertiary education in order to further their careers—careers that they know can only be enhanced by their own hard work and their own effort. Senator Faulkner chooses to denigrate those senators when many of the people that he referred to who have a law degree used that law degree to further their careers in many other fields, because their tertiary qualifications and their knowledge of the law helped them to be able to further their careers in whatever their chosen field is.

The difference is that there is a wide variety of occupations on this side of the chamber. Many of your trade union members have law degrees. I have worked with Senator Bishop for a considerable time and I understand that he has a law degree. In many of the conversations I have had on committees with Senator Bishop, he has talked about studying for a law degree. I know that other members on that side have them as well.

On this side of the chamber some people have got law degrees to try to get themselves through their professional careers, to further themselves, to be self-employed, to work for themselves, not to latch on to a trade union so that at some later stage in their career they may find their way into this chamber via the trade union movement. Very few people on this side of the chamber have actually achieved their positions in the Senate because they happen to have a law degree, but many people on that side of the chamber are in the position they are in because they were trade unionists and because they had the support of their trade unions to get here.

Most of the people on this side of the chamber have had to work their way through the organisation and be selected by their peers, or be selected by their electoral colleges, to make sure that they represent a wide variety of professions and a cross-section of the community in order that they can more widely represent the people in their home states. That is quite different from the people sitting on that side of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —I wish to take note of Senator Alston's answer today. As he has done on a number of other occasions in an attempt to deflect from his own inadequacy to answer any particular question—like Senator Kemp—Senator Alston chose to criticise the Labor opposition for what he regards as unrepresentativeness in terms of the number of former union officials on this side of the chamber. speech.para: I can recall numerous cases of people being abused, wrongfully dismissed or harassed in their occupations who were defended by my trade union. My father was in politics, and he gave me a piece of advice which I have always regarded as very good advice when dealing with political opponents. He said that there are three things that you do not touch on in politics: the background of your political opponent; their personal lives; and their physical appearance. talk.start.para: —Well, he has delivered for us, hasn't he?

Those three principles of my father's are ones which personally I have always held in this chamber. I think it is important to hold them. speech.para: I do not come into this chamber drawing attention to the fact about lawyers. But it is not just lawyers—look at the National Party with all its farmers.

The speech read as follows—

As every election approaches, 1.4 million teachers, posties and other public servants who might like to stand for parliament have to decide whether it is worth resigning their jobs in order to do so. Australian citizens who also are citizens of another country have to go to great lengths to repudiate their dual citizenship if they want to nominate for election.

Section 44 of the Constitution is the problem. It stops anyone who holds an `office of profit under the Crown' or who is a citizen of another country (as well as Australia) from nominating for parliament.

talk.start.para: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1998 sets the maximum operating grants for universities in 1999 and 2000, thereby confirming in legislation for the first time the government's massive cuts to university operating grants which were announced in 1996. speech.para: It is noted that this bill has been redrafted to combine two pieces of legislation into a new consolidated bill. Part of the legislation was deal with in the previous parliament, but not passed by the Senate, and the other part was only introduced into the House of Representatives.

The opposition is especially critical of the haste in which this new bill has been introduced and the lack of time that has been given for scrutiny of the bill. We believe this to be characteristic of the way in which this government has handled its legislative program, and specifically its approach to higher education.

The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, who clawed his way into cabinet over the body of Senator Vanstone, is only too happy to use education as a scapegoat for every national problem that he can think of. But he is now most anxious to avoid public debate on his administration. We saw a clear indication of the lack of will of this government to discuss education during the election campaign when, in a most shabby way, they released the Liberal's education policy at 5 o'clock one evening in such a manner as to ensure that there was no examination of the details of that platform. One can understand why Dr Kemp is anxious to avoid public scrutiny of his policies, because under this government the very nature of tertiary education, the very nature of the creative features of our education system, has been fundamentally changed.

Australia has seen a contraction in the efforts of its education sector and a greater emphasis within the universities on commercialisation at the expense of the traditional role of providing high quality, broad based education of Australian people. We have seen an underlying position of greater emphasis on vocational education within the university sector which this government believes will create more jobs—an assumption which has yet to be demonstrated in fact. Sadly, the narrowing of the focus of our university sector has impacted on every aspect of university life and has resulted in less choice and an inferior quality of education in our universities across this country.

The very nature and role of academics has been supplanted by the more market driven approach adopted by the government itself. In the past, academics were proud of the role they played in essential and healthy debate within this country. In the past, academics were proud to be associated with public controversy to stimulate debate and questioning of society and the directions that society was taking. However, our academics are no longer encouraged to espouse views and positions which in the past were essentially the mainstream discourse of public life.

Under this government there has been a shift whereby there is an overriding atmosphere of fear and intimidation where academics are stifled, morale has plummeted and controversy is feared. Likewise, universities have been bludgeoned into accepting a narrower, market driven criteria for their very operations. What we have seen was recently demonstrated by Barry Jones—I think quite adequately—at the inaugural RMIT student union lecture series in Melbourne in August this year. He pointed out that the failure of Australia's universities to fight for the traditional values of scholarship or to contribute to debates on controversial issues has meant that governments can attack them with impunity. He pointed out that, in his experience as Minister for Science, he saw the precedent for this set, whereby the Liberal Party, which is essentially made up of philistines and various forms of ignoramuses—
